title: Sun-drenched destination 5 hours from UK is 'full of colour' in winter | Travel News | Travel
text:
The southernmost stretch of Italy enjoys sunshine all year round (Image: Getty) With winter in full swing, Britons are turning their gaze to warmer locales for a seasonal retreat, and one destination that has come to be known for its beauty in Winter is Italy 's largest island.
Travel bloggers strongly believe that Sicily should be at the top of the travel list this winter, and there are several reasons why.
The southernmost stretch of Italy is drenched in sunshine year-round, making it alluring to Britons seeking much-needed warmth.
The destination comes highly recommended by travel blog @alidalifetravel on TikTok , who took to her social media platform to highlight the wonders of visiting Sicily in the winter.
“You want to visit Sicily in the winter,” the content creator affirmed. “It’s the southernmost area of Italy with a lot of sunshine.”

The Italian gem stays open throughout the year, welcoming smaller crowds and lower prices during winter months, as temperatures drop slightly.
“It’s absolutely gorgeous in the winter,” continued the blogger. “Yes, some of the restaurants and beach bars might be closed, but if you stick to the cities like Catania, Siracusa, Palermo, Agrigento, and Taormina, you will have no problem finding really good places.
“The really good ones stay open throughout the year because the really good ones don’t base their business model on tourism but on the local communities.”
“The local communities have very high standards in terms of food.”

The Lonely Planet echoes many of these points in its guide for the region, adding that winter visitors can still expect citrus trees to be heavy with ripening fruit.
“Magical Sicily is full of colour in winter [...]. Food market stalls in Catania and Palermo creak under the weight of fresh vegetables, fish and seasonal walnuts; and all over the islands locals are preparing the Carnavale.
“While the weather can change at the drop of blood orange, eight hours of sunshine a day and average highs reaching double those in London make it worth taking your chances."
A quick internet search shows that flyers can get from London to Catania, in no more than 5h40, for just £73.
